posts.name: Andrey
posts.cooked: Hi. We are trying to improve our pose estimation so we can do better autos. We have two cameras connected to a Pi and they work great. When there is an April tag visible, the pose is very accurate. However, during those periods when no April tag is visible, we have to rely on odometry and it’s not very accurate. We checked all our constants and debugged the data we get from encoders, all of that looks correct. My guess is the problem has to do with friction and slippage of the wheels. The faster we go, the higher the error. The swerve pose estimator assumes that the number of wheel rotations translates to distance traveled, which is not really the case. Before we try to invent a “creative” way to correct for this, I wanted to check if there is any standard way to handle this or if anyone has any other ideas?

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
The first sanity check is to go very slowly (to eliminate gross wheel slippage) and make sure that’s dialed in for odometry only.

36 inches should be 36 inches. (Or longer if you can manage it.)

90° should be 90°

We found that our assumptions about constants were wrong.

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked:
After you do slow, move that up to game speed and repeat.  And then don’t command higher than that speed.

Last year for a bit we accidentally were squaring the commanded velocity.  So the robot was behaving similarly odd, where only very low speeds would drive reasonably.  So that is something to be aware of.  If was basically the max speed was applied twice, we should have been using a 0-1 input instead of a 0-maxSpeed.
posts.display_username: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.cooked:
A few thoughts from my team’s experience with debugging pose estimation:

The easiest and most obvious first step is to ensure that if you drive forward slowly some distance, the robot actually registers that distance. This discounts any error in constants, such as gear ratio + wheel circumference. If the constants are incorrect, you will see your position error increase linearly with the distance traveled (e.g., drive 1 meter, the robot thinks it has gone 1.1 meters; drive 2 meters, the robot thinks it has gone 2.2 meters). Keep in mind that your wheel circumference isn’t actually the circumference of your wheel; it’s the WORKING wheel circumference. We found it’s best to calibrate this number (move the robot some distance, see what distance we traveled, see what difference we should have traveled, add a fudge factor). Keep in mind that the fudge factor should only be used if your error is increasing linearly with distance driven. Another approach to getting this “fudge factor” is to rotate the robot in a circle using the gyro, compare how far each module should have gone vs how far they actually went. There’s a pretty good post by 6328 on this website somewhere.

Another common reason that odometry data may be very wrong could be wheel slippage, which happens when you request accelerations outside your robot’s limits. There isn’t really a way to account for this solely in odometry; you should really stop the robot from skidding in the first place. Some potential ways to do this could include:

slew rate limiters on x, y, omega

custom acceleration limiting stuff

swerve setpoint generator with pathplanner, Swerve Setpoint Generator | PathPlanner Docs Also, you should set good stator current limits on your motors in addition to one of the solutions above. Here are relevant CTRE docs: Swerve Setpoint Generator | PathPlanner Docs All of the above is dedicated to avoiding wheel slip, but it doesn’t account for what happens if your wheels actually do slip (your odometry will get messed up). If you really want to account for wheel slip in your odometry, check out the relevant portion of Orbit 1690’s software lecture: https://youtu.be/N6ogT5DjGOk?t=1681 . Imo it’s pretty hard to use skid detection with the WPILib SwerveDrivePoseEstimator, so I wouldn’t rlly recommend it (assuming thats what you are using. All in all, you should still get good results without.

One more thing you could try, although you shouldn’t really NEED this for accurate odometry, is higher frequency odometry. From my team’s experience, if your odometry is alr inaccurate, this isn’t going to fix anything, but it does make pure odometry more reliable. CTRE docs: Factors that Impact Odometry I think 6328 also did some testing with this at some point and made a pretty nice post, but I couldn’t find it anywhere.

Follow-up question: How inaccurate is your odometry really? How are you measuring it? Some amount of inaccuracy in your odometry is to be expected, that’s why we have vision; it really depends on how much and over how long.

Hope this helps!

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
Great stuff above!

#1 tip is to actually set current limits… good for all the things that ail your robot #2 is definitely “make sure that the commanded distance is the ACTUAL distance”.  You need to ACTUALLY tape measure it.  Wheel measurements are not enough.  Published swerve data is NOT enough.  Too many places to mess up….

All the other stuff above is also totally spot on!!!

posts.name: tkchan
posts.cooked: Another way to calibrate your wheel’s dia is to just program a spin 1 revolution and look at the wheel distances has traveled.  Compared the 2 and you can get a better estimate on your wheel dia.  In that short of time, your gyro drift should be small enough to not be an issue (spin more than 1 rev if you want to confirm)

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: think outside of the box from time to time

posts.custom_user_title: think outside of the box from time to time

posts.cooked:
SM695:

All of the above is dedicated to avoiding wheel slip, but it doesn’t account for what happens if your wheels actually do slip (your odometry will get messed up). If you really want to account for wheel slip in your odometry, check out the relevant portion of Orbit 1690’s software lecture: https://youtu.be/N6ogT5DjGOk?t=1681 . Imo it’s pretty hard to use skid detection with the WPILib SwerveDrivePoseEstimator, so I wouldn’t rlly recommend it (assuming thats what you are using. All in all, you should still get good results without.

Alternatively, deadwheel odometry will always track accurately no matter how much you slip.  Deadwheels are the standard in FTC , as our (lack of) drive wheel traction makes them a necessity for high-performing autos.  TBH, I see no reason you couldn’t also add a Pinpoint to an FRC bot.  You would need to make your own pods with FRC -scale omni wheels, but a basic swingarm design is very easy to make (its just an omni wheel with an encoder that sits on a arm that pivots).

posts.cooked:
Here is a relevant thread that goes over the potential drawbacks/benefits of using deadwheel odometry in FRC . Also, I was under the impression that mechanum wheels tend to slip more than standard treads. In that case, wouldn’t slipping affect the accuracy of deadwheels as well?

Viability of tracking wheels for better odometry in FRC? Technical

Viability of tracking wheels for better odometry in FRC? Technical

link_counts.title: Viability of tracking wheels for better odometry in FRC?

posts.cooked:
SM695:

In that case, wouldn’t slipping affect the accuracy of deadwheels as well?

The whole idea of deadwheels is that they are “dead”, i.e., undriven wheels completely independent of your drivetrain.  Regardless of what wheels you use for your drivetrain, deadwheel odometry pods use omni wheels mounted at 90 degree offsets sprung into the floor.

posts.name: Andrey
posts.cooked:
Thanks for all the suggestions. Yesterday I ran about a dozen tests with constant speeds (10%, 15% and 40% of max speed) and measured actual distance traveled with tape measure. It looks like pose estimation is off by 5%-10% in either direction (sometimes overestimates, sometimes underestimates). I would actually be ok with that kind of error, but I’m pretty sure it’s worse when we accelerate and turn. I will try to measure error in those scenarios next.

Based on these results though, it doesn’t seem to me that constants are the issue.. I would expect it to be consistently over or under if constants were off.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
Andrey81inmd:

Based on these results though, it doesn’t seem to me that constants are the issue.. I would expect it to be consistently over or under if constants were off.

I agree and think you need to dig deeper on the wheel-odo-only measurements. I would expect you could easily get slow speed straight-line errors down under 2% (2.5 inches over 10 feet). (We didn’t carefully measure our repeatability, but it was good enough that we moved on and there’s no way we’d move on if it was 5-10% off.)

Cover up/disable all the cameras. Use straight wheel odometry only. Cap speed at 10% of max and motor power to 25% or so. Line the wheels up ahead of time. Move 10 feet, measure it, tweak, repeat until you get that down in the 0-2% range.

If those measures are off by 5+%, I think you need to work with mechanical and/or a mentor to figure that out or you’re building your house on top of a foundation of marshmallow.

(That doesn’t mean you need to halt all other work until you sort this out, but I think you should get it sorted out fairly soon from a start-with-the-basics approach.)

I don’t want to derail the topic from OP’s question, but if your actual wheels are slipping, why wouldn’t your deadwheels slip? In my mind, your actual treads can get much more friction than the omniwheels. Why wouldn’t your deadwheel also slip if your robot is slipping?

posts.name: Isaac Proctor
posts.cooked:
The drive wheels slip from the motors applying more torque than the friction between the treads and carpet can handle, so the wheels end up spinning faster than they are moving the robot. The deadwheels are just being pushed around by the robot’s movement, and don’t have any significant amount of resistance to prevent them from moving, so they just rotate along with the rest of the robot.

Hope that made sense.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
Can you post your results?  Those sound kind of terrible…  Real motivation for this thread!!!

Your starting point needs to be slow speed with slow ramp up/down and tape measured distances.  There’s no sense in checking faster until you have slow -nailed-.  As long a span as you can reasonably work with!  One wheel rotation is only a foot-ish; you need a bunch of rotations to make the error in the tape measure a minor factor. Note the comment about aligning the wheels before you start!

Another item:  This may sound silly, but I suggest you put a tape or marker mark on each wheel.  Lift the robot (power is off) and clock all four wheels with the mark down.  THEN do a short test; maybe 4 feet or so.  See if the marks are all still clocked the same way.  You might have a wacky problem where one or two wheels are fighting the others!

Watching/videoing the wheels during this escapade is worth bonus points

Another exotic problem is the logic around dealing with steering 0 and 180 vs wheel forward/reverse.  You MIGHT have something going on with this switch in the code.

posts.name: Andrey
posts.cooked:
We identified one problem, which was that one wheel was larger than others (one Cohlson wheel was brand new and the rest worn out). Switched it out and ran the tests again. We don’t have that much space so some of these are shorter tests. Here are the results.

image 514×435 10.4 KB

image 514×435 10.4 KB

image 514×435 10.4 KB

It looks like it’s always overestimating, but by different amounts. Longer tests and faster speeds seem to give better accuracy.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: What are you actually measuring here?  You really want actual wheel rotations, but commanded distance can work.  And a careful tape measure between a hard part of the robot and something hard that doesn’t move, like a field element.

posts.name: Andrey
posts.cooked:
I’m measuring actual distance traveled (using tape measure) and distance traveled according to swerve pose estimator. I can measure wheel rotations also.

That reminds me of another question I’ve been meaning to figure out. We report a lot of metrics to SmartDashboard, but it’s kind of a pain to use. Unless we explicitly record the data and store it, we can’t go back and look at it. And half the time we load a recorded session, it freezes. I’m used to tools like Grafana that allow you to go back and look at any telemetry data. Is there anything similar available for FRC ? I was thinking to spend some time to make grafana work with this architecture, but curious if anyone has attempted this.
